answers.answer: When I was diagnosed, my first A1C came in at 7.5 and my doc was not happy.  He does not care if I test or not because the A1C is more accurate, but I find that testing helps keep me in line with my diet.  I think if I had a doc who would not prescribe me the test strips, I would start looking for a new doc.  And if I had a doc who gave me no more than two minutes on a twice yearly basis, I would be looking for a new doc.I test every am, and every evening.  It is suggested that we test first thing in the am, 1 hour before a meal or two hours after, and before bed.  My insurance only covers 2 strips a day, so I alternate when I take it.FYI...from everything my doc has said and everything I have read, the A1C should be below 6.

Thanks Often - I appreciate your information.  This helps.I have been thinking I need to change drs; however, this is a very small town and though there is another doctor I like in the same medical facility, the medical facility will not let us change within their group.  Ugh.  I think I'm pretty much stuck with her.I need to educate myself as to a good diet for me.  I've never changed my diet from when I was diagnosed because I really don't know what I should be eating.  Of course, I know what I SHOULDN'T be eating and will work from that angle.  I do exercise, but not sure if I should be doing more.Thanks again,

Diet and exercise are very important.   For diet, you need to limit carbs and sugars.  I was told 3-4 carb servings per meal...2 of them starch, but whole grain is preferred.  A carb serving is 15g.Obviously, eliminate sugar as much as possible.  Pepperidge Farm has a decent low carb bread  9 g per slice.An afternoon and evening snack, 1-2 carb servings    4 oz oj or a small orange, small apple, half banana   each of those would be a carb serving.Whole fruit vs juice.Small portions...you can check out the ADA or the Joslin site for help, although the ADA for sure seems to want mostly to sell stuff.  Check out books at the library.  Start reading labels for carb/sugar content.Hopefully, all this will help and you can get your numbers lowered despite the doc.  I would also explain to her that it helps you monitor yourself and that you would appreciate it if she would prescribe the test strips for you ... you are, after all, paying her.

Thanks again Often.I'm going to try to take a more pro-active role here and learn as much as I can.  I do fairly well with keeping up with exercise -- I'm not a couch potato.  We live in the mountains and lots of beautiful places to walk.  However, I'm going to Curves today to set up a plan.  Though I walk a lot, I'm not getting my heart rate up and hope this will help in that area.I know no one can change this but me.  I definitely need to learn more about diet and plan to do that.I have a tremendous amount of stress in my life right now and anything I can do to help my own health would be beneficial for those around me.Wish I could change doctors to one who is more supportive and especially informative, but that's probably not going to happen right away.Thanks again for your help.  I truly appreciative it.

I am a 5'6", 49yr old female who was diagnosed with Type II in January of 2006.  It runs in my family, and there have been many deaths and amputations because of it.  Fortunately, my doctor belongs to a hospital with a diabetes center, so I was able to get a lot of information.  I have also been online a lot gathering information.When I got diagnosed, I was 212lbs, and am now down to about 169lbs My A1C was 6.5, and is now down to normal ranges.  At this time, if I were to be tested with no past testing, I am NOT considered diabetic.  YEAH!!!!  What I have done is, been very careful about what I eat, and the amount of it.  I have 45 carbs per main meal, consisting of a protein, a vegetable (not including corn or peas), a carb (which can include peas or corn), a fruit and calcuim.  If I want something like ice cream or chocolate, I eat it early in the day, but only in very small quantities......1/4 cup of ice cream.  I do not eat that kind of food often, but when I get a craving for it, I eat it.  I was told it is better to eat what you crave in small amounts, than to not eat it at all and go nuts about it.At this time, I do not formally exercise as I am physically very active, but when the winter comes, I have a motorized treadmill, tension bands, and weights to  keep my body fit.I don't use sugar, but splenda, as the other sugar substitues taste horrible. I totally enjoy soda, so I drink caffine free diet pepsi and a kool ade like substance from 4C, which is similiar to Crystal Lite, but again, has Splenda.I too, take Januvia, but only 5mg daily.  My body is suseptible to medications, therefore, I don't require large doses of anything.    Before being prescribed it, I would get hypoglycemic on a daily basis, and couldn't do anything for more than an few hours, and then would have to rest.  I even collapsed in our local grocery store, and had to have an ambulance.  Very embarassing.Don't give up.  I do agree about finding another Dr. if possible. There is a lot of information online than can help you learn about what you have and how to take care of yourself.Regarding testing, I do it every other day, because my sugar is currently under control.  Before, I would do it twice a day, as suggested by "OFTEN".I hope this helps.

You definately need a new doc!  Try to find a rheumatologist that specializes in diabetes. With a A1C test of 7.5 you should be controlling your diet. Do you take any medication? Please get a new doc. Complications from diabets are debilitating, and can be life-threatening.

I had a similar issue with a "too busy" doc in a practice that didn't allow switching primary docs... it was really awful; I finally had to switch to a practice in another town which was inconvenient, but what a difference a good and caring doc makes!Anyway, I too had to self-educate.  One site I found helpful was:http://www.healthcentral.com/diabetes/I liked the way it is set up; easy to navigate and a nice mix of information and forums.I also found a lot of info, especially about diet, on about.com, but wow is that site difficult to navigate... if you find a page you like, be sure to bookmark it because you might never find it again otherwise!  Here's a link to a page there about carbohydrates:http://lowcarbdiets.about.com/od/lowcarb101/a/carbintro.htmI was able to control my blood sugar through diet and lifestyle changes, and hopefully you can too!  And hopefully you'll be able to find a better doc soon... good luck!

question: Need some information.  I've been told I have diabetes for a few years now.  My mother recently dided with complications of diabetes and my one sister is on insulin w/poorly controlled diabetes.  I asked my doctor what my last AIC number came in at and she said 7.5.  Should I test?  I do test when I don't feel well and wonder if blood sugar is to blame.  I'm on Glipizide XL 2.5mg and Januvia 100 mg.My doctor is not a strong proponent of testing unless on insulin.  She did order me 100 test strips over a year ago with no refills and when I recently asked for another prescription of test strips, she wrote a prescription for 25 w/no refills.I'm just not sure if I should be doing more.  I see my doctor every six months and the appointment (I've timed them) lasts between 90 and 120 seconds.  I sometimes have questions unrelated to diabetes that take up this time.Just wanting to know if I'm on track.  I really don't have a lot of guidance here and I'm thinking it's because this is not severe diabetes and I realize that - but I want to keep it under control if possible, but not sure how to do that.Thanks,
title: How often should I test?
